Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on February 25, 2021 in response to an open records request. The data -- which in some cases merged penalty amounts from multiple violations --was a spreadsheet version of information contained in individual case documents that can be retrieved at https://www.ahs.dep.pa.gov/eFACTSWeb/default.aspx

Secondary Offense: child labor or youth employment violation
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Info Source: https://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/6-15-10b.cfm
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: Teavana agreed to pay a $3.75 million civil penalty to settle allegations that it knowingly failed to report to CPSC, as required by federal law, that its tea tumblers contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard or that the tumblers created an unreasonable risk of serious injury.
Info Source: http://www.cpsc.gov/en/Newsroom/News-Releases/2016/Teavana-Agrees-to-Pay-375-Million-Civil-Penalty-for-Failure-to-Report-Hazardous-Tea-Tumblers/

Private Litigation Case Title: Summer York v. Starbucks Corporation et al
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/448887/judge-backs-starbucks-3m-meal-break-settlement

Private Litigation Case Title: Matamoros et al v. Starbucks Corporation

Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/264856/starbucks-pays-1-6m-to-settle-managers-ot-action

Court: Northern District of California; Central District of California
Private Litigation Case Title: Carr et al v. Starbucks Corporation; Olivia Shields, et al v. Starbucks Corp, et al
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/829224/000089102002000519/v80964ex99.txt
Notes: On April 19, 2002 Starbucks issued a press release saying it had agreed to pay $18 million to settle two lawsuits challenging the status of Starbucks California store managers and assistant store managers as exempt employees under California wage and hour laws.

Description: Starbucks agreed to pay $225,000 to the District Attorneys of Monterey, Shasta and Sonoma counties to resolve allegations it failed to refund gift card balances to customers.
Info Source: NorCal DAs reach settlement with Starbucks, Associated Press, August 18, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: violations of the New York City Paid Safe and Sick Leave Law
Info Source: https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2019/attorney-general-james-and-mayor-de-blasio-announce-settlement-starbucks

Description: Starbucks agreed to settle this suit alleging that it systematically violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to give job applicants timely notice that consumer credit reports might be used against them in the hiring process. The settlement involved payments ranging from a $125 gift card to $840 in cash plus the gift card for each class member. No estimate of the total cost to the company was cited in the court documents. Starbucks also paid $20,000 to the class representatives and $1,285,000 for the plaintiffs' legal fees.
Private Litigation Case Title: Wills v. Starbucks Corporation; Rosario v. Starbucks Corporation
Info Source: https://www.prweb.com/releases/francis_mailman_soumilas_wins_settlement_approval_in_nationwide_class_action_suit_against_starbucks/prweb17269458.htm
